Congratulations on completing your charity 5K run and setting a personal best! Incorporating bike rides into your running training can be a great way to improve your overall cardiovascular fitness and endurance, which can ultimately help you shave off time from your running personal best. Here are some tips on how to incorporate bike rides into your running training:

1. **Cross-training**: Bike rides can be a great way to cross-train and reduce the impact on your joints compared to running. This can be especially helpful if you're experiencing injuries or need a low-impact alternative to running. By incorporating bike rides into your training, you can maintain your cardiovascular fitness while giving your running muscles a break.
2. **Interval training**: Use your bike rides to incorporate interval training, which can help improve your running performance. For example, try alternating between high-intensity cycling and active recovery (e.g., easy spinning) to mimic the intensity fluctuations of running. This can help improve your anaerobic endurance and increase your lactate threshold, which can translate to faster running times.
3. **Endurance building**: Long, steady-state bike rides like your 20-mile ride along the lake trail can help build your endurance and increase your aerobic capacity. This can translate to improved running endurance and the ability to maintain a faster pace over a longer distance.
4. **Incorporate brick workouts**: Brick workouts involve combining two or more disciplines, such as cycling and running, in a single session. For example, try riding your bike for 30-60 minutes, followed by a 10-20 minute run. This can help your body adapt to the transition from cycling to running and improve your running efficiency.
5. **Focus on cadence and pedaling efficiency**: Pay attention to your pedaling technique and try to maintain a high cadence (80-100 RPM) to improve your running efficiency. This can help you develop a more efficient running stride and reduce your risk of injury.
6. **Incorporate strength training**: In addition to bike rides, incorporate strength training exercises that target your core, glutes, and legs. This can help improve your running economy and endurance.
7. **Periodize your training**: Make sure to periodize your training and incorporate bike rides into your routine in a way that balances with your running training. Aim to do bike rides on non-consecutive days to allow for recovery time between sessions.

Some general tips to improve your running performance:

1. **Incorporate speed workouts**: Incorporate speed workouts, such as interval training or hill repeats, to improve your running efficiency and endurance.
2. **Incorporate strength training**: Incorporate strength training exercises that target your core, glutes, and legs to improve your running economy and endurance.
3. **Focus on proper running form**: Focus on proper running form, including maintaining good posture, landing midfoot or forefoot, and keeping your arms relaxed.
4. **Gradually increase your mileage**: Gradually increase your weekly mileage to allow your body to adapt to the demands of running.
5. **Get enough rest and recovery**: Make sure to get enough rest and recovery time between runs to allow your body to recover and adapt.

Remember to listen to your body and adjust your training accordingly. It's also important to consult with a healthcare professional or a running coach to develop a personalized training plan that suits your needs and goals. Good luck with your training!
